results.title: Fleetwood Mac (this is the one)
results.brief_description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed.

constellations_primary.name: Film and TV dreams
constellations_primary.description: Fleetwood Mac's 'Dreams' coasted its way back up the charts 40 years after it was first released, thanks to Nathan Apodaca's joyous viral TikTok, but Fleetwood Mac (and Stevie Knicks) have been main staples of screen culture for decades.

results.description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed. The 22-second viral video sparked countless imitations, with Apodaca’s wholesome performance giving the world some long overdue joy.
description_for_label: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed. The 22-second viral video sparked countless imitations, with Apodaca’s wholesome performance giving the world some long overdue joy.

results.title: In the beginning
results.brief_description: A colourful clay animation film which satirizes society and its impulse to invent nuclear weapons which cause self-destruction. Looks at the invention of destructive weapons from raspberries to rockets! Narration: Brian Woods. Animation: Mark D’Arcy-Irvine, Masfufah Sani. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.

results.title: Pentimento
results.material_description: interactive software, video, infra red lights and projection
results.brief_description: PENTIMENTO is based on real events which took place in the Blue Mountains on the outskirts of Sydney, during 1999, involving the discovery of an unidentified body. It fictionalizes these events to dramatize some of the key elements surrounding the murder and the sexual violence which formed its backdrop. It presents these events in the form of recollections from the point of view of a father, sister, brother and the crime scene itself.

results.title: Tractor goth girl
results.brief_description: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.
description_for_label: TikTok user gutknot challenges misogynistic assumptions that women can’t operate farm machinery. A response to her video dancing to country song ‘International Harvester’ suggested she “probably [didn’t] know how to start a tractor”. Well, she proved him wrong and gained over 3.4m views in four days. Part of the popularity of the video is the juxtaposition of the goth aesthetic with an agricultural setting usually associated with conservatism, but it also relates to the broader y’allternative hashtag. A play on ‘yall and alternative, the movement provides an online space for leftist, LGBTQIA+ and goth folk living in rural areas.

results.title: Thor: Love and Thunder
results.brief_description: Thor: Love and Thunder sees Thor (Chris Hemsworth) embark on a journey of self-discovery – which is suddenly interrupted by a galactic killer, Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks to eliminate the gods.

constellations_other.name: Marvellous and magic MCU inventions
constellations_other.description: In Thor: Love and Thunder, the iconic weapons Mjölnir and Stormbreaker are joined by new additions like Zeu's Thunderbolt - they're just a long line of enchanted and technologically advanced weapons in movies.

constellations_other.name: Physical transformation and the formation of character
constellations_other.description: Christian Bale is hardly recogniseable as villain Gorr the God Butcher in Thor: Love and Thunder. It’s just another instance of the actor drastically changing his appearance to inhabit a character – and he’s not the only one.

constellations_other.name: Mayes C Rubeo
constellations_other.description: Emmy-award winning and Oscar-nominated costume designer Mayes C Rubeo has worked on some of Hollywood's biggest blockbusters, designing costumes for characters and creatures across time, space and everything in between.

results.description:
Thor: Love and Thunder sees Thor (Chris Hemsworth) embark on a journey of self-discovery – which is suddenly interrupted by a galactic killer, Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks to eliminate the gods.

Thor joins forces with King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and, to his surprise, ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who now wields Mjolnir as the Mighty Thor, to understand the mystery of Gorr’s vengeance and stop him before it’s too late.

Featuring 25 costume changes for Thor alone, the film is a visual feast. “Thor’s sort of searching for his identity, and that’s represented in his wardrobe,” Chris Hemsworth reflected. “The costumes and the sets aesthetically match the energy of the film — they’re another colour to the painting.”
description_for_label:

results.title: Don't Shoot the Messenger
results.brief_description: “Visuals recorded live at a digital meditation in cyberspace performed during the Mayday dance party 1993. A series of computers and cameras were interconnected, manipulated realtime and projected.” Sourced from VHS cover slip for Don’t Shoot the Messenger

results.title: Darling Darling
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst
Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30 mins.
SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames
Courtesy the artist
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.
